messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Gregory Weidman <delrayva@...>
wrote:
>

>
> This goes, then, to how I solve my 32-33-34 problem with QS. I
basically have no distinction in my speech between Ah (32) and Ox
(34). When a word is spelled with an "o" in T.O., I use "Ox." When
it is spelled with anything other than an "o" in T.O, then I use "Ah."
Well, not exactly. When the "o" is the schwa sound, I use "Utter."
I think this is perfectly in line with KR's approach with Roe --
Where there is ambiguity in dialectical pronunciation, then QS
defaults to the closest obvious mapping to T.O.
>
> So, at the end of the day -- I don't think an IPA mapping is a good
idea. Rather, a set of dialect-specific minimal pairs with some rules
for resolving ambiguities in favor of approximating T.O. is probably
the best way to capture the phoneme distinctions that KR was trying to
get at, while facilitating effective communication among those with
divergent dialects.
>

Good story! At this point, as I am just starting to learn QS, when I
see anything that looks like #34, I simply look up the word. I cannot
at all distinguish between #33 and #34. So I rely on standard American
English. (On the other hand, I just got some birthday money and went
out and bought the Longman dictionary because it is the only one that
uses IPA, and wouldn't you know it, I got home and it merges #33 and
#34 as well!) My approach is pretty inefficient, though. I don't want
to have to use a dictionary.

I am sympathetic towards your approach. I do have one quibble, though.
I think #32, #33, and #34 can be mapped to IPA. Note how John Cowan,
who is against the IPA mapping, imediately used the IPA when I told
him about the confusion between #32, #33, and #34. (You hypocrite,
John! Joke.)

None-the-less, given the problems that are discussed on this thread,
something like your approach may be needed. As just one example, I
don't know if I would want to read a whole book in Australian dialect,
unless the book was fiction and the dialect really added something, as
Huck Finn does.

So I think your approach, or something similar, is what we are heading
towards. To this end I just looked up the vowels in Australian English
to see what differences existed and how those vowels would be
expressed in QS, but I can't quite read the IPA for Australian yet.
(What does ":" mean after a symbol?) I really want someting specific,
something that does away with the inadequacies of the Read manual. I
would like for QS to be mapped to IPA, but I think there are too many
dialects to do so. If we spoke a language that did not have so many
dialects, we might be able to.

(On the other hand, thiking aloud, Germany has dialects that are so
different that a German from the North has trouble understanding a
speaker from some regions of the South, yet Germany has one very
simle, effective phonemic alphabet.)

So if you could submit some examples of "dialect-specific minimal
pairs with some rules for resolving ambiguities" that would be a start
in the right direction. Or at least that would move the debate forward.

Paul
